body_content.explanation: a flat raised area or structure
a long, flat raised structure at a railway station, where people get on and off trains:
examples: The next train for Aberdeen will depart from platform 9.

body_content.explanation: the raised part of the floor in a large room, from which you make a speech or give a musical performance:
examples: Speaker after speaker mounted/took the platform to denounce the policy.
This brilliant young violinist has appeared on concert platforms all round the world.

body_content.explanation: the people who are up on a platform in order to speak to an audience:
examples: An elderly lady stood up and said she had a question for the platform.
The platform party (= the group on the platform) applauded loudly.

body_content.explanation: a style of shoe with a very thick high sole (= bottom part):
examples: Flared trousers and platforms were in then.
Strappy heels or even clunky retro platforms can look good.

body_content.explanation: an opportunity to make your ideas or beliefs known publicly:
examples: By refusing to give us a grant to make this programme, they are denying us a platform.

body_content.explanation: all the things that a political party promises to do if they are elected:
examples: We campaigned on a platform of low taxation.

body_content.explanation: the type of computer system or smartphone you are using, in relation to the type of software (= computer programs) you can use on it:
examples: This new personal banking software can be used with any Windows platform.
Both Apple's iOS and Google's Android mobile platforms now have emoji keyboards built into their software.

body_content.explanation: (of shoes) having a very thick high sole (= bottom part):
examples: She borrowed her mother's platform shoes.
When I started high school, those huge platform sandals were all the rage.
